Ask: Why is it important to deeply understand all of these different market?
There are 2 primary reasons to do this: 
You need to see if your business has a place in the market given the competition, economy, customer needs, etc…
Investors doing due diligence will want to see that you know the ins and outs of your business. You should show that your product/service has a large market and it is growing. You need to convince them that based on all of this research/information, you are a good bet.
If you consider all of these factors, you are likely to find big trends that will either help or hurt your business. It is very important to understand these points at the very beginning. So you can capitalize on them or avoid risks.

Recap: As you are in these first stages of your business, make sure you evaluate these points. It is up to you to determine what is most important for you to research to ensure the success of your business.

1-2 minutes: Lecture

There is so much that goes into the research phase of starting a business. We can spend months or even years researching an idea! Although research is important, you don’t want to get sucked into only doing research and never making progress on your business. We want to learn some of the key points, and begin to start testing and building our products. Research is ongoing throughout the development of your business (rather than a long period at the start)
We will go over 3 market research elements today. If we talked about a point earlier that you think is important for your business, you should conduct that as well! You should look at the needs of your individual business and make a plan to research what you need. 


The market analysis section of your feasibility study will cover these 4 points:
Market size: How big is the market you will be competing in? How many people are willing to pay for what you are offering? Market sizing should also consider long-term trends—such as consumer demand for sustainable products or shifts in energy costs.
Competitive analysis: Who is currently in this space? What are their strengths and weaknesses?

## **Task 1: Module Summary**
### **Core Learning Objectives:**
- Introduce participants to **design thinking** as a problem-solving framework.
- Guide entrepreneurs through **market research, competitive benchmarking, and financial feasibility**.

- **Market Research:** Understanding market size, competitive landscape, and barriers to entry.
- **Competitive Benchmarking:** Identifying competitors and differentiating value propositions.
- **Budget Planning:** Evaluating financial feasibility and startup costs.

- Improved ability to **assess market potential** and structure business ideas.
- Enhanced skills in **benchmarking competitors** and identifying unique selling points.
- Stronger grasp of **financial planning** for early-stage businesses.
